pros: More vacation days than in a typical job. Dependants can attend college for free, paying only fees and books.
cons: If you don't have a doctorate degree you are treated as if you should t have an opinion, regardless of how much experience you have in a particular subject. You are also expected to follow directions and listen to people who have zero knowledge about a particular subject simply because they are members of he president's cabinet. It is very political and while they want it to appear that you have autonomy and are able to work independently, you basically are a micromanaged pupet. Everyone complains about these things behind the backs of the administration but fear for their jobs to the extent they refuse to address these issues when given the opportunity.

review_title: Great school for students- poor administration: Low pay & out of touch Management
job_title: Recruiter, Enrollment Coordinator, Extended Campus in Gaffney, SC
pros: Small college environment, flexible to support family needs. Extra vacation during Christmas, leave early on Fridays during the Summer months. Day Admissions team is awesome! They are eager to help students and other departments. Academically, Limestone College is a great place for students. Military- friendly college.
cons: Horrible pay for mid-level and below employees. Due to the nature of a small, private college- talented young professionals are poorly paid and are not promoted. Whereas, those who have been with the college for 20+ years inherit positions due to seniority and not on merit. For the employees with less than 5 years tenure, be prepared to not have a valued opinion, and overlooked for promotions. Financial Aid department is a joke- for students and for faculty/staff. Phone calls go unanswered and never returned. This small college environment breeds career professionals who sit and stay, even when unqualified and lack vision.

pros: Easy going and friendly work environment. Not a stressful job. Get most school holidays off, so December was nice. Being paid once a month was tough at times, but you get used to it.
cons: Ethics were terrible. Very few males or other races than white worked there. HR department was below par. AS a record keeper there, the office was slow to process some forms and at times had problems with the legalities of some teachers. Did not do background checks on employees who were previously hired from activation date....TERRIBLY idea. Push for and only hire those with a degree. Once I was hired I learned the my degree was just a statement. I did not use my previous knowledge nor was I rewarded for having a degree. I also had a lady who I worked with sue the college for mold being in her office.

pros: Some academic freedom - for example, your superiors aren't breathing down your neck
cons: The system is more complicated than it needs to be; too many systems (e.g., portal, blackboard, jenzabaar, weave, navigate) all with good intent but way more complicated than need be. Textbook fiasco. No chance for advancement or raise. I'm teaching 6 classes and making 39,000. I'm also a member of various committees. And even with summers technically off, I'm expected to be doing work. There seems to be little appreciation for hard work.

pros: There's a new president, so I am hoping things will be better.
cons:
There's a new president, so I am hoping things will be better.  But 5 months in, I am not sure things are changing for the better.  

As we transition, there are a lot of back door dealings.  There are people in leadership positions who use their positions to intimidate others.  There is no consistency in expectations or pay.  There is very little transparency and some of the efforts to make people feel part of the process seem to be for show.

review_title: Clueless and arbitrary at the top
pros: Two weeks off (paid) in December, in addition to regular vacation days.
cons: Strictly a top-down organization. No input from those on the front line (staff, faculty or even students) solicited or encouraged -- in fact, just the opposite.  As one VP said, "After all, we are the experts." So folks in a bubble make all the decisions based on disconnected group-think. Then, when things go south, the ones who are actually doing the work are blamed for it and usually fired [or rather, "their position has been eliminated"]. ZERO accountability from the President and Executive VP, while the college is in serious decline financially because of their decisions, resulting in more than 30 recent layoffs and unpaid furlough for the remaining. Administration demonstrates no loyalty to its employees.

job_title: Preceptor of English in Gaffney, SC
pros: Everyone there is so close and goes out of his/her way to help me.  Being a college professor is amazing in general. I am off by 2 to get my son, and I get summers off.  My classes are small and I only teach 5 a week instead of 5 or 7 a day as I did when I taught high school.
cons: The paperwork can be overwhelming at times, but I love the freedom from non-testing.  Plus, I am an English teacher so the paperwork is unavoidable.

pros: 2 weeks off (paid) in December.
cons: Totally top-down mgmt. Totally clueless as to reality on the ground. Academics petending they know how to run a business, while desperately needing the business to succeed or the ship goes down.
